Author: thaumaturgy
Content:
That's exactly what they're targeting here -- Alienware's existing (and not altogether small) market, full of gamers, geek chic, and those that might wear t-shirts advertising their hackitude.

Designers look at it and wince, but I can definitely see that phone being successful in that crowd.

EDIT: Argh. I should've paid closer attention to the text. As others pointed out, this thing's completely fictional. They're not targeting anything. Mea culpa.

Author: wallflower
Content:
If you don't already have a alpha/beta/gamma of your web application live, I think a prototype of an interesting web project would help raise your application's chances. That being said, interesting ideas are cheap - my goal is to put the time/effort/energe to mold one of my ideas into a live proof-of-concept/prototype by the application deadline... in basically one month's time.. in Ruby on Rails (which I've just started learning).

The fact that GMail started out from humble beginnings ("I wrote the first version of Gmail in one day. It was not very impressive. All I did was stuff my own email into the Google Groups (Usenet) indexing engine." - http://tinyurl.com/2zs4pe) is inspiring.

Content:
My vote goes to Xobni.

The founders are both great guys and they're solving an ugly problem that millions of people care about. I'm a GMail user myself now, but it's unlikely Outlook is going anywhere anytime soon.

I'm kicking myself for not pushing Adam to let me invest when I met him in Boston.

Author: ericb
Content:
>>shouldn't two instantiations of the same pattern be the same consciousness?

No--they will never occupy the same coordinates as each other in time and space, and therefore can't be the same consciousness, by definition.

The "I" doesn't have to be entirely an illusion, but our understanding of can be wrong.

I didn't used to like dark chocolate. Now I do. Which "version" is the real me, the one who doesn't like dark chocolate, or the one who does?

Author: wallflower
Content:
I've started doing this again. If you're introspective, it's hard to find someone to talk to about your life - Writing your thoughts and feelings down is immensely therapeutic - it's like listening to yourself.

I use a private, password-protected blog (TypePad) and can even use their mobile interface. I find paper diaries can be hard to use as you have to establish a habit, while since most of us are always online in some form - it's easier to journal digitally.

I did do lots of journalling years ago (using a bound paper diary) during a difficult workaholic phase and it is painful to read the self-pity and negativeness of the entries. But, it is good to see how I've changed since then.

Author: wallflower
Content:
I've bought tens of self-help/self-discovery books and even read some of them. Of those I've read, I've found lots of commonalities and themes.

The most important theme, in my mind, which is echoed in successful startups and businesses is: You don't have to get it right, you just have to get it going..." (as Mike Litman puts it)

Author: paulgb
Content: Not only is the picture totally a speculative mock-up (see the original image here: http://image.alienware.com/Images/product_detail_page_images...), if you read carefully there is no indication that alienware is actually building a phone at all. Really this is just some guy making up stuff about a phone, in order to have the "exclusive" and get backlinks from people too clueless to realize he's making it all up.

Author: jksmith
Content:
What strikes me about sql is that new programmers think even the smallest shrinkwrapped desktop app that persists data has to ship with a db engine with a sql interface. The ultimate result is all this modelling that's done to generate SQL for your interfaces using some fancy toolkit. The problem with this is that it creates an appearance of separation by generating a bunch of business objects for you. But it still encourages designing interfaces with data access in mind = monolithic development.

SQL is especially good for those times when you do not have all the answers for the questions that may be asked of your data. But if you already know all the ways your data will be queried, what's the point?

Author: yters
Content:
By saying consciousness is a pattern in the flux of matter, you are echoing my point that consciousness can't be based on the particular matter. So, if you then think consciousness is the pattern, shouldn't two instantiations of the same pattern be the same consciousness?

Sorry we're going in circles here, but I do not understand your jump in logic. We aren't talking about identity in terms of how to pick a particular consciousness out of a set. We're talking about the subjective experience of "I", and I have a hard time seeing how any of those identifiers give me my sense of continuity.

It is also completely impossible for me to consider the "I" to be an illusion, because I am involved in the very act of trying to escape myself. It is just as incoherent as saying there is no truth, or the law of non contradiction doesn't hold. You can tell yourself such things if you want, but you can't do so in an intellectually honest way, since intellectual honesty presupposes these concepts.
